title: Mike Reinbach
text:
Michael Wayne Reinbach (August 6, 1949 – May 20, 1989) was a <a href="corner%20outfielder">corner outfielder</a> and <a href="designated%20hitter">designated hitter</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> who played for the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a> in <a href="1974%20Baltimore%20Orioles%20season">its 1974 season</a>. Listed at 6' 2", 195 lb., Reinbach batted left handed and threw right handed. He was born in <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego, California</a>.
Career and life.
Reinbach was selected by the Orioles in the <a href="1970%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20draft">1970 MLB draft</a> out of <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Los%20Angeles">University of California, Los Angeles</a>, where he played for their <a href="UCLA%20Bruins%20baseball">UCLA Bruins</a> baseball team.
His rise through the Orioles <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">Minor League</a> system was highlighted by a splendid 1972 season, hitting a .348 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> with 31 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s, 113 <a href="runs%20batted%20in">RBI</a>, and a 1.087 <a href="on-base%20plus%20slugging">OPS</a> between AA and AAA while being named <a href="Southern%20League%20%281964%E2%80%932020%29">Southern League</a> <a href="most%20valuable%20player">most valuable player</a>, to become the <a href="Southern%20League%20Most%20Valuable%20Player%20Award%23Winners">first player to win this award in the league's history</a>.
He appeared in 12 games in his only season at Baltimore, going 5-for-20 for a .250 average with a <a href="double%20%28baseball%29">double</a>, two <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a> and two <a href="run%20batted%20in">RBI</a>.
Reinbach opened 1975 at Triple A <a href="Rochester%20Red%20Wings">Rochester Red Wings</a>, where he batted .290 with 11 home runs and 62 RBI and was selected to the <a href="International%20League">International League</a> All-Star team. He then joined the <a href="Hanshin%20Tigers">Hanshin Tigers</a> of <a href="Nippon%20Professional%20Baseball">Nippon Professional Baseball</a> during five seasons spanning 1976–1980, becoming immediately a Tigers fans favorite for his timely hitting and solid play at <a href="first%20base">first base</a> and <a href="right%20field">right field</a>. Overall, Reinbach hit .296 with 94 homers and 324 RBI in 545 games for Hashin and earned <a href="Best%20Nine%20Award">Best Nine Award</a> honors in 1979.
In six minor league seasons, Reinbach hit .284 with 68 homers and 331 RBI in 674 games. In between, he played winter ball with the <a href="Navegantes%20del%20Magallanes">Navegantes del Magallanes</a> club of the <a href="Venezuelan%20Winter%20League">Venezuelan League</a> during the 1973-74 tournament.
Reinbach retired after his 1980 season at Japan and spent most of the decade as a pioneer in the burgeoning home computer industry. He was killed in an automobile accident in 1989, when his car went off a precipice in <a href="Palm%20Desert%2C%20California">Palm Desert, California</a> while driving to <a href="Palm%20Springs">Palm Springs</a>. He was 39 years old.
